## Cartesian product
---
Given two sets **X** and **Y**:

* X = {a, b, c}

* Y = {1}

The cartesian product is **every possible pairing** of X with Y, so

|       | a          | b         |
|---    |--------    |-------    |
| **1**     | (1 ,a)     | (1, b)     |

---

Like wise, if **X** and **Y** were:


* X = {a, b, c}

* Y = {1, 2, 3}

The cartesian product (X x Y) would be:

|       | **a**    | **b**       | **c**       |
|---    |-----    |-----    |-----    |
| **1**     | (1,a)     | (1,b)     | (1,c)     |
| **2**     | (2,a)     | (2,b)     | (2,c)     |
| **3**     | (3,a)     | (3,b)     | (3,c)     |

## Binary relations
---
If set **Z** is a subset of set **X** x **Y** then **Z** is a binary relation between **X** and **Y**. More concisely:

**Z ⊆ X x Y**

---
### Example:

X x Y:

|       | **a**    | **b**       | **c**       |
|---    |-----    |-----    |-----    |
| **1**     | (1,a)     | (1,b)     | (1,c)     |
| **2**     | (2,a)     | (2,b)     | (2,c)     |
| **3**     | (3,a)     | (3,b)     | (3,c)     |

Z: 

|       | a          | b         |
|---    |--------    |-------    |
| **1**     | (1 ,a)     | (1, b)     |

R is a subset of X and Y since **Z ⊆ X x Y** (Z is contained or equal to X x Y)

## Injective, Surjective and Bijective Functions --- ### Function (**f : X -> Y**) Let **f** be a binary relation between **X** and **Y**. f is a function of X in Y if: 1. If given **any** (x,y) and (fx, fy) elements, when fx = x then fy = y. (So every x has an unique *image* fy). 2. **f**'s *domain* must be **all** of X. > *Terminology*: In a (fx,fy) pair from f, we'll refer to **fy as the image of fx** and inversely to **fx as the counter image of fy**. More generally, we'll refer to **image of f** as all the "set of all fy" and **domain of all f** as all the "set of all fx". --- Example: X = {1, 2} Y = {1, 2, 3, 4 ,5} f = {(1, 1), (2, 4)} f is a function of X in Y since: 1. Every x has an unique image (1 -> 1, 2 -> 4) 2. f's domain has all of X ( (1, 2) and (1,2) ) A counter example would be if we reverse X and Y since in that case f would not even a binary relation since f contains elements that do not exist in X x Y (proof as exercice for the reader) --- ### Injective, Surjective and Bijective Once understood the previous point. This one is trivial. Let **f : X -> Y**. Then **f** is.. * Surjective: If every image of f has one counter image * Inyective: If every image of f has **at least** one counter image * Bijective: If every image of f has **exactly** one counter image [](https://www.pdfprof.com/PDF_Image.php?idt=107406&t=40)

## Sets: finite, infinite and enumerable 
---

## Finite

A set is **finite** if it's empty or **has n elements**.

A set has n elements if there's a bijective function from {1,2,3,...n} in the set. Also called **cardinal n**.

## Infinite

A set is infintie when it's not finite.

---
## Enumerable 

A set is enumerable  if it's finite **or** there's a bijection from N in X.

> N as if in set of natural numbers

---
### Examples

Z is enumerable since we can define it with the following function:

f(x) = -x/2 if x is even

f(x) = (x-1)/2 if x is odd

And this function is bijective so Z is enumerable.

> Proof: Just equal f(x<sub>1</sub>) = f(<sub>x2</sub>) for any x that is even and then forany y that is odd. In both cases you'll get that x<sub>x1</sub>=x<sub>2</sub> 

Since it's numerable then there's a bijective function from N to Z so N is a subset of Z yet they both have the same amount of numbers

> Note: We're refering to N as natural numbers and Z as whole numbers

## Number of functions

Say we have a set Y of cardinal n. How many functions f can exist in Y?

First let's look at **one** possible function of f : {1, 2, 3... r}  -> Y

> From now on we'll refer to {1, 2, 3.. r} as **N<sub>r</sub>**

Let's say N<sub>r</sub> = {1, 2, 3} and Y = {a, b}

Then one possible function would be the binary relation f = {(1, a), (2, a), (3, b)}

> Reminder: this means f(1) = a, f(2) = a, f(3) = b

> From now own we'll just write that as **aab** since it's shorter to write

But another one could be abc, or aaa or bab, or.. you get the idea. It's every possible combination of a, b up to 3 characters, that is, the **variation**. In a more general way all the possible functions would all the possible **n** combinations of **r** length/size

In order to calculate this variation(aka **every possible combination**) let's make use of a tree diagram:

Y = {a, b}

N<sub>3</sub> = {1, 2, 3}


![Tree](https://i.imgur.com/iCrazYP.png
)

As you might see, for every column **r** from N<sub>r</sub> there's **n** choices from Y so first column is 2, then for every one of those two there's another two so 2·2, for every one of those 2·2 there's another two so 2·2·2

So the answer is 2<sup>3</sup>. In a more general form, all the possible combinations are:

> VR(n, r) = n<sup>r</sup>

And as we saw at the beginning. All the possible combinations are just all the possible f : N<sub>r</sub> -> Y that there can be so this result is all the possible functions in this case.

---

### Example 1

How many functions can we make of N<sub>7</sub> in Y = {0, 1}

> nº of functions = VR(2, 7) = 2<sup>7</sup> = 128

### Example 2
Is there a set Y such that you can define 512 functions of N<sub>3</sub> in Y? And of N<sub>4</sub>?

Let's imagine there is and it's cardinal is n, so:

> nº of functions = VR(n, 3) = n<sup>3</sup> = 512

> n = 512<sup>1/3</sup> = 8

So any set X of cardinal 8 will have this many functions of N<sub>3</sub>

As for N<sub>4</sub>:

> n = 512<sup>1/4</sup> = 4.75

It's not a whole number so no. However 5 would contain more than that, but not 512 exactly.

## Number of injective functions

**Important: Please refer to Number of functions if you haven't read that part yet**

Say we have a set Y of cardinal n. How many functions injective f can exist in Y(cardinal **n**)?

As we saw in the last chapter the number of functions of the form 

> f: N<sub>r</sub> -> Y

Is nothing but the number of all possible **n combinations of length r**, which is **n<sup>r</sup>** (so the variation)

However, in an injective function there can't be repeated counter images

> Reminder: f = {(1, a), (2, b), (3, a)} would not be an injective function since f(1) = f(3)

So the answer is n combinations of length r **without repetition**. How do we find this out?

Let's try to deduce the answer through an example. We have:

> N<sub>3</sub>, Y = {a, b ,c}

Similar to in **Number of functions** we'll use the same tree diagram but with a very important difference:

![tree](https://i.imgur.com/K6mj0X2.png)

Now on every column instead of giving the choice of every element in Y we'll take out the one that has already been previously chosen 

---

### Bijective functions

If n = r then it's a bijective function since it'll be both injective and have all of N<sub>r</sub> mapped. That means that it'll be surjective and since it's both injective and surjective that means it's bijective.

---

## Example 1

How many numbers below 100 with two different digits can you write using only 1, 3, 5 and 7?

Our input space is {1, 3, 5 ,7}. With this set we can make numbers of two digits like

f : {1,3,5,7} -> 54

or

f : {1,3,5,7} -> 13

Problem is merely asking how many functions can exist like these other two. It also says digits don't repeat so it's asking how many injective functions there are, which, as we just saw earlier, is :

> 4·3 = 12

## Example 2

In a bookshell there's 6 different books. How many ways can we rearrange them?

We could either think of this similar to example 2 with a function that simply possibly changes the order of books like 

f : {a, b, c, d, e, f} = {b, a , e ,c , d ,f}

So number of possible functions is:

> 6·5·4·3·2·1 = 720

Since books can't repeat (problem doesn't specify they can magically be cloned)
